map_node.indicator_name: Housing Maintenance: Pre-1960 Homes with Peeling Paint
map_node.indicator_description: Older housing and peeling paint can put residents at risk of lead poisoning, due to lead paint - which was banned from household paints in the USA in 1978.

dataset.how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint n areas greater than 8.5" x 11", divided by the total number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
dataset.discription: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

unreliable_text: * Estimate is based on small numbers so should be interpreted with caution.

show_disparities_node.disparitiesPagetext: When population health or the quality of living environments varies by population characteristics such as income or race, there is disparity. One way to visualize disparity is to chart indicators of health or environment across levels of neighborhood poverty. We categorized neighborhoods as high, medium or low poverty. Then we took the median of the neighborhood-specific values in each category. The median is the middle of the sorted group of values.
show_disparities_node.indicator_name: Housing Maintenance: Pre-1960 Homes with Peeling Paint

Link.graph_title: Housing Maintenance: Pre-1960 Homes with Peeling Paint

info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint n areas greater than 8.5" x 11", divided by the total number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

info.info_how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.

link_data_node.linkDataPagetext: The "Link Data" function shows associations between environmental health data at the neighborhood level using <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Scatterplot" target="_blank">scatterplots.</a> The points represent x and y values for each NYC neighborhood. The pairs of indicators available for scatterplots were chosen because previous research suggests that one may either directly or indirectly cause or contribute to the other. Because the data being charted are <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Ecological_Study" target="_blank">ecological</a> and not individual level, and because many factors contribute to the health of a population or environment, the patterns seen in these charts do not necessarily represent the underlying causal relationship.

info.y_axis_title_reg: Renter-occupied homes with any health-related maintenance problems
info.info_name: Renter-occupied homes with any health-related maintenance problems
info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting any health-related maintenance problems (cockroaches, mice or rats in the building, cracks or holes in walls, ceilings or floors, leaks from outside, toilet breakdowns, lack of air conditioning, heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, or broken plaster or peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches),divided by the number of renter-occupied households in the area; expressed as percent..
info.info_source: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)
